body.p: The annual Faculty of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Conference will be held in Melbourne 10–12th October 2013 at the Melbourne Conference and Exhibition Centre Southbank. A preconference workshop day will be held on Wednesday 9th October with workshops on eating disorders, borderline personality disorder in youth and anxiety and sleep disorders in younger children.

The conference has been titled Snakes & Ladders to reflect the need for fun and play in our work, as well as to capture the ups and downs of work with children and young people and their families. The subtitle Continuities and Discontinuities: in Development, Families and Communities captures the centrality of developmental context and transitions, both for individuals and families, in our work with children and young people and their families. It also captures our effort to recognise the discontinuities between our communities and those who suffer greater disadvantage and constricted resources in neighbouring regional countries as well in our indigenous communities. We have made child and adolescent global mental health a conference theme, and hope the conference will begin a greater engagement between Australian and New Zealand child and adolescent psychiatrists and child mental health professionals from neighbouring regional countries.

The conference aims to be inclusive of Child and Adolescent Psychiatrists, Psychiatrists working with youth and Paediatricians working with the mental health of children and young people and their families. We have worked to ensure it is equally relevant to those in public and private practice. It is hoped that the conference will bring stronger linkages between all working with children and youth.
Invited international and local speakers include:

list-item.p: Professor Olayinka Omigbodun a Nigerian Child and Adolescent Psychiatrist and currently President of the International Association of Child and Adolescent Psychiatrists and Associated Professionals (IACAPAP), whose interest is in child and adolescent global mental health
Associate Professor Helen Egger from the Duke Developmental Epidemiology Program at Duke University (USA), whose areas of interest are developmental epidemiology, childhood anxiety disorders
Professor Brian Lask (UK), whose expertise is in eating disorders including the treatment and neurobiology of eating disorders
Professor Pat McGorry (Melbourne), whose expertise is in youth psychiatry and who has been instrumental in leading the current reforms in Australia in youth mental health
Professor Frank Oberklaid (Melbourne), who will speak about policy and program challenges in the mental health agenda for young children
Professor Bruce Tonge (Melbourne), who will speak about emotional and behavioural interventions in children with developmental disorders

body.p: Speakers will present in plenary, symposium and workshop format. There will also be a wide array of local Australian and New Zealand presenters.
Important themes for the conference will be:

list-item.p: Psychotropic medication use in children and adolescents
Global child and adolescent mental health particularly as it relates to the Asia-Pacific region
Complex patients and the interface of public and private practice and
Headspace and structural reform with youth mental health
Indigenous child and adolescent mental health
The mental health needs of children and young people from refugee backgrounds
Anxiety and other emotional disorders in very young children

body.p: As well as the academic side the conference provides a friendly and social setting to meet others and forge or rekindle friendships and professional relationships. A number of social and artistic events are planned for the conference.
For more details please see our website www.child2013.com.
